current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend title 10, United States Code, to require the Secretary of Defense to conduct periodic
			 mental health assessments for members of
			 the Armed Forces and to submit reports with respect
			 to mental health, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Jacob Sexton Military Suicide Prevention Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Jacob Sexton Military Suicide Prevention Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Annual mental health assessments for members of the Armed Forces
Annual mental health assessments for members of the armed forces

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , not less frequently than once each calendar year, the
shall provide a person-to-person mental health assessment for—

text.#text: Subject to
each member of the armed forces on active duty; and

each
			 member
			 of the Ready Reserve of an armed force.

The purpose of a mental health assessment provided pursuant to this section shall be to identify
			 mental health conditions among members of the armed forces in order to
			 determine which such members are in need of additional care, treatment, or
			 other services for such
			 health conditions.
The mental health assessments provided pursuant to this section shall—

of this
			 title with respect to a mental health assessment provided pursuant to such
			 section; and

text.#text: Not less frequently than once each year, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall include, with respect to assessments conducted pursuant
			 to this section during the one-year period preceding the date of the
			 submittal of such
			 report, the following:

text.#text: Each report required by
The number of members who received an assessment.
A description of the tools and processes used to provide such assessments, including—
whether such tools and processes are evidenced-based; and

the process by which such tools and processes have been approved for use in providing mental
			 health assessments.
A description of the mental health conditions detected through such assessments.

The number of members referred for care and services based on mental health conditions detected
			 through such
			 assessments.

Such recommendations for improving the monitoring and reporting of the number of members who
			 receive care and
			 services based on such referrals as the

Such recommendations for improving the tools and processes used to conduct such assessments,
			 including tools that may address the underreporting of mental
			 health conditions, as the
No personally identifiable information may be included in any report under

Any medical or other personal information obtained under this
			 section shall be protected from disclosure or misuse in accordance with
			 the laws on privacy
			 applicable to such information.

shall, in consultation with the other administering Secretaries, prescribe

text.#text: Not later than 120 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Jacob Sexton Military Suicide Prevention Act of 2014/s:3/ss:a

text.#text: The duties of the interagency working group convened pursuant to

To review existing programs that can be used to improve the provision of accessible, timely, and
			 high-quality
			 mental health services to members of the National Guard and the Reserves.

To recommend new interagency programs and partnerships to improve the provision of such mental
			 health services to such members.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, States, and
			 private and academic entities	to improve the provision of mental health
			 care to members of the National Guard and the Reserves.

Department of Health and Human
			 Services

text.#text:
To recommend best practices for partnerships among the

, the interagency working group may consult with

			 agencies,

			 appropriate.

text.#text: No personally identifiable information may be included in any report required by

header.#text: Exclusion of personally identifiable information from reports

Report on improvements in the identification and treatment of mental health conditions and
			 traumatic brain injury among members of the Armed
			 Forces

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Armed Services of the Senate

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
a report
			 setting forth an evaluation of specific tools, processes, and best
			 practices to improve the
			 identification of and treatment by the Armed Forces of mental health
			 conditions and traumatic brain injury among
			 members of the Armed Forces.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Committee
			 on Armed Services of the House of Representatives

text.#text: Not later than one year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Jacob Sexton Military Suicide Prevention Act of 2014/s:4/ss:a

text.#text: The report under

An evaluation of existing peer-to-peer identification and intervention programs in each of the
			 Armed Forces.

An evaluation of the Star Behavioral Health Providers program and similar programs that provide
			 training and certification to health care providers that treat mental
			 health conditions and traumatic brain injury in members of
			 the Armed Forces.

An evaluation of programs and services provided by the Armed Forces that provide
			 training and certification to providers of cognitive rehabilitation and
			 other rehabilitation for traumatic brain injury to members of the Armed
			 Forces.

An evaluation of programs and services provided by the Armed Forces that target members of the
			 Armed Forces
			 and family members affected by
			 suicides among members of the Armed Forces.

An evaluation of tools and processes used by the Armed Forces to identify traumatic brain injury in
			 members of the Armed Forces and to distinguish
			 mental health conditions likely caused by traumatic brain injury from
			 mental health conditions caused by other factors.

An evaluation of the unified effort of the Armed Forces to promote mental health and prevent
			 suicide through the integration of clinical and non-clinical programs of
			 the Armed Forces.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Jacob Sexton Military Suicide Prevention Act of 2014/s:4/ss:b/p:1..6

text.#text:
Recommendations with respect to improving, consolidating,
			 expanding, and standardizing the programs, services, tools, processes, and
			 efforts described in

A description of existing efforts to reduce the time from development and testing of new mental
			 health and traumatic brain injury tools and treatments for members of the
			 Armed Forces  to widespread
			 dissemination of such tools and treatments among the Armed Forces.

Recommendations as to the feasibility and advisability of establishing preliminary mental health
			 assessments and pre-discharge mental health
			 assessments for members of the Armed Forces, including the utility of
			 using tools and processes in such mental health assessments that conform
			 to those used in other mental health assessments provided to members of
			 the Armed Forces.

Recommendations on tracking changes in the mental health assessment of a member of the Armed Forces
			 relating to traumatic brain injury,
			 post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, anxiety, and other conditions.

text.#text: In this section:

term.#tail:
means a mental health assessment conducted with respect to an individual before the
			 individual enlists in the Armed Forces or is commissioned as an officer in
			 the Armed Forces.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail:
means a mental health assessment conducted with respect to an individual during
			 the 90-day period preceding the date of discharge or release of the
			 individual from the Armed Forces.
